ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If the student didn't know much semantics already I would certainly recommend this course as an excellent introduction and overview. If they knew a lot of semantics already I might not think it was suitable for them
Yes, I would, but only someone who has a fair amount of background in semantics, or who knows a little bit of logic.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course for me was primarily a way of acquiring a particular skill that I can bring to bear in other aspects of me research. To some extent I was unprepared then for how independently interesting I think the material is: I'd definitely like to learn more in the future. It was very satisfying to go to a talk by a visiting linguist at the end of the semester and found I understood far more of the talk than I would have had I not taken the course. That experience confirmed for me how much I had picked up through taking the course.
It is a great foundational course for anyone who is interested in philosophy of language or semantics, and Ben taught an excellent course.
